Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 208,.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 208, Section 28, the Probate and Family Court has jurisdiction to modify custody orders upon a showing of a substantial and material change in circumstances.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts case law, including Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704(1985), establishes that a custodial parent seeking modification must demonstrate that the proposed change is in the best interests of the child and that there has been a material change in circumstances affecting the child's welfare since the entry of the original order.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation case decided in the context of an initial divorce judgment, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding. The opinion interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulates the ‘real advantage’ and best‑interests standards for removal, but it does not discuss or require a showing of a material change in circumstances since a prior custody or visitation order. Therefore it does not establish the two‑part ‘material change plus best interests’ standard for modification described in the proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815) … .”}
